title: Handling Biomass Measurements

Several crop-specific guides harvesting weighing tissue. R function accepts information crop harvest record sheet stores convenient data structure. Additional R functions calculate key variables raw measurements reorganize results convenient format. Together, features provide straightforward system obtaining data creating full record analysis. collecting measuring plant material, complete description data can created follows: Store images completed crop harvest record sheets directory. Store commands used digitize process data (ones Full Example section document) R script directory. Save final biomass data table plain-text file directory using write.csv. Now final biomass values available simple CSV format, exact steps taken analyze data clear anyone looks directory future, including ! Even though details might immediately apparent script, documentation functions BioCroField describe calculations made. rest document explains types biomass measurements important context crop growth modeling (Biomass Leaf Area section), general steps required collect tissue field (Harvesting Material section), general steps required weigh tissue (Weighing Tissue section), BioCroField can used process resulting data (Processing Data BioCroField section). final section (Full Example) shows realistic example functions BioCroField can used process full biomass data set field season. title: Handling Biomass Measurements
text: farmers crop scientists want compare productivity different fields varieties, use quantity called yield, can defined amount harvested material per unit area. loose flexible definition; type harvested material depends particular crop question; amount can specified volume, weight, mass; several systems units customarily used different locations around world. Nevertheless, yield proven useful concept, least partially intrinsic property depend size field crops grown. interesting note harvested material per plant far less useful. crops grown higher densities, competition plants increases, plant tends produce less output. Thus, harvest per plant depends crop’s inhererent productivity also degree competition plants. hand, often fairly wide range plant population (number plants per unit area) can result identical similar yield; example, maize Illinois sown April 5 May 5 can reach 97% higher maximum yield populations 24,000 36,000 plants per acre (Nafziger 1994). Thus, circumstances, yield (per area basis) better reflects true productivity crop without complicating influence competition. context crop growth modeling, typically interested predicting yield (mass per unit area) particular crop variety particular location. , however, generally necessary predict amount plant components (masses per unit area), following: Leaf: amount leaf mass determines amount carbon crop able assimilate process photosynthesis, leaf mass critical calculating growth rates. Root: amount root mass determines amount water nitrogen crop able obtain soil. Litter: crop ages, begins lose tissue process senescence. lost mass recycled parts plant, remainder shed, forming litter. competing processes growth senescence determine masses components like leaf root. Total: Besides components mentioned , crop also uses carbon grow stem reproductive material like flowers pods. accurate predictions, essential accurately model distribution carbon throughout crop components. Therefore, validate crop model, important experimental measurements crop components, ideally multiple times throughout growing season. addition masses, critical measure leaf area index (LAI), defined leaf area per unit ground area, also plays key role simulating photosynthesis canopy level (Bréda 2003). model able reproduce mass leaf area measurements, can faith able make accurate yield predictions situations.

title: Handling Biomass Measurements
text: make measurements important quantities, necessary sow multiple plots harvest plants single randomly-chosen plot several times throughout growing season, ending final harvest. plot also contain wire mesh litter trap known area, harvest generally include following steps: Choose section row known length; count plants contained row section; cut stem just ground; collect -ground portions plant bag dried weighed. can provide estimates population, -ground biomass (AGB) per unit area, AGB per plant. measurement, length row containing approximately 1-4 dozen plants (depending size spacing) used. Choose smaller number sequential plants (often half dozen); cut stem just ground; dig clean roots plants; split -ground portions plants components stem, living leaves, senesced leaves still attached plant, reproductive parts like flowers pods; collect separate component bag dried weighed. Combined AGB measurements , process can provide estimates mass per area partitioned component. also provides second estimate AGB per plant can compared one determined previous step determine whether plants chosen paritioning representative plot whole. Measure total area living leaves partitioned previous step. process can provide estimate specific leaf area (SLA), defined leaf area per leaf mass. SLA leaf mass per unit area determined previous step can used estimate LAI. Collect litter fallen litter trap put bag dried weighed. Combined senesced material still attached plant, can provide estimate litter formed process senescence. Note importance drying collected tissue weighing. wet weight can vary greatly throughout day give accurate reflection amount material truly incorporated structure crop. instance, two meters freshly cut sorghum plants often weighs two meters freshly cut maize plants, maize often heavier drying sorghum retains water stems. Pictures illustrating key parts harvest process can found Images Field vignette (available online).

title: Handling Biomass Measurements
text: harvest_point function BioCroField designed digitize data one crop harvest record sheets. names input arguments function generally match fields present crop harvest record sheets, making simple straighforward transfer values sheet computer. example, completed crop harvest record sheet might look like following image: Example completed crop harvest record sheet. represents information single biomass harvest performed 2022-08-23, soybean (var. GM4000) harvested plot 3 UIUC. row spacing plot 0.7 m, 150000 plants per acre. row section 2 m long harvested -ground biomass; section included 47 plants, total dry weight 1100 g. Six plants used partitioning; total leaf area 9000 cm^2, dry leaf mass 35 g, dry stem mass 55 g, dry root mass 15 g, dry pod mass 30 g. leaf, stem, pod components plants form total -ground biomass. Finally, litter trap plot area 0.2 m^2 found contain 3.2 g leaf litter 1.5 g stem litter. plant material dried 14 days weighed. Note: real data, GM4000 real soybean variety, although values reasonable typical commercial soybean cultivar. case, following command can used store information sheet R data structure: output function harvest_point object represents information sheet. technical point view, harvest_point object just R list particular set named elements. information stored can viewed standard R commands like print str. example: information available via built-help system typing ?harvest_point R terminal.
code: hp <- harvest_point(   crop = 'soybean',   variety = 'GM4000',   location = 'UIUC',   plot = 3,   year = 2022,   doy = 235,   planting_density = 150000,   row_spacing = 0.7,   partitioning_leaf_area = 9000,   partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 35, stem = 55, root = 15, pod = 30),   agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem', 'pod'),   agb_row_length = 2,   agb_weight = 1100,   trap_area = 0.2,   trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 3.2, stem_litter = 1.5),   partitioning_nplants = 6,   agb_nplants = 47 ) str(hp) #> List of 20 #>  $ crop                          : chr "soybean" #>  $ variety                       : chr "GM4000" #>  $ location                      : chr "UIUC" #>  $ plot                          : num 3 #>  $ year                          : num 2022 #>  $ doy                           : num 235 #>  $ hour                          : num 12 #>  $ planting_density              : num 150000 #>  $ row_spacing                   : num 0.7 #>  $ plant_spacing                 : num 0.0385 #>  $ partitioning_nplants          : num 6 #>  $ partitioning_leaf_area        : num 9000 #>  $ partitioning_component_weights:List of 4 #>   ..$ leaf: num 35 #>   ..$ stem: num 55 #>   ..$ root: num 15 #>   ..$ pod : num 30 #>  $ agb_components                : chr [1:3] "leaf" "stem" "pod" #>  $ agb_nplants                   : num 47 #>  $ agb_row_length                : num 2 #>  $ agb_weight                    : num 1100 #>  $ trap_area                     : num 0.2 #>  $ trap_component_weights        :List of 2 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 3.2 #>   ..$ stem_litter: num 1.5 #>  $ additional_arguments          : list() #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "harvest_point" "list"

title: Handling Biomass Measurements
text: often useful include information seeds originally sown, sowing date initial biomass per unit area field, even though truly “harvest” information. details can included biomass data table (created biomass_table) using add_seed_biomass function BioCroField. operation included Full Example . information available via built-help system typing ?add_seed_biomass R terminal.

title: Handling Biomass Measurements
text: section, provide example biomass data three separate harvests combined table along information initial seed mass. Note: real data, GM4000 real soybean variety, although values reasonable typical commercial soybean cultivar. Now can take look final data values: also easy graph :  Optionally, final biomass table can saved CSV file R data file; one commands included processing script:
code: # Specify some pieces of information that are the same for all harvests crop <- 'soybean' variety <- 'GM4000' location <- 'UIUC' year <- 2022 agb_row_length <- 2 planting_density <- 150000 row_spacing <- 0.7 trap_area <- 0.2 partitioning_nplants <- 6  # Store the measured data values as a list of harvest_point objects biomass_measurements <- list(   harvest_point(     crop = crop,     variety = variety,     location = location,     plot = 2,     year = year,     doy = 185,     planting_density = planting_density,     row_spacing = row_spacing,     partitioning_leaf_area = 500,     partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 2.5, stem = 1.5, root = 1.4),     agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'),     agb_row_length = agb_row_length,     agb_weight = 50,     trap_area = trap_area,     trap_component_weights = list(),     partitioning_nplants = partitioning_nplants,     agb_nplants = 46   ),   harvest_point(     crop = crop,     variety = variety,     location = location,     plot = 3,     year = year,     doy = 235,     planting_density = planting_density,     row_spacing = row_spacing,     partitioning_leaf_area = 9000,     partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 35, stem = 55, root = 15, pod = 30),     agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem', 'pod'),     agb_row_length = agb_row_length,     agb_weight = 1100,     trap_area = trap_area,     trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 3.2, stem_litter = 1.5),     partitioning_nplants = partitioning_nplants,     agb_nplants = 47   ),   harvest_point(     crop = crop,     variety = variety,     location = location,     plot = 1,     year = year,     doy = 275,     planting_density = planting_density,     row_spacing = row_spacing,     partitioning_leaf_area = 0,     partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 0, stem = 40, root = 13, pod = 175, seed = 130),     agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem', 'pod'),     agb_row_length = agb_row_length,     agb_weight = 1000,     trap_area = trap_area,     trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 45, stem_litter = 15),     partitioning_nplants = partitioning_nplants,     agb_nplants = 51   ) )  # Convert measured values into masses per area in BioCro units processed_biomass_measurements <- lapply(biomass_measurements, process)  # Specify mass values that should be set to zero when not explicitly measured zero_when_missing <- c('pod', 'leaf_litter', 'stem_litter')  # Reorganize values into a data frame soybean_biomass <- do.call(   biomass_table,   c(processed_biomass_measurements, list(zero_when_missing = zero_when_missing)) )  # Add the initial values to the data frame soybean_biomass <- add_seed_biomass(   soybean_biomass,   year = year,   doy = 152,   seed_mass = 0.17,   zero_when_missing = zero_when_missing,   component_fractions = list(leaf = 0.8, stem = 0.1, root = 0.1) ) str(soybean_biomass) #> 'data.frame':    4 obs. of  29 variables: #>  $ crop                        : chr  "soybean" "soybean" "soybean" "soybean" #>  $ variety                     : chr  "GM4000" "GM4000" "GM4000" "GM4000" #>  $ location                    : chr  "UIUC" "UIUC" "UIUC" "UIUC" #>  $ plot                        : num  NA 2 3 1 #>  $ year                        : num  2022 2022 2022 2022 #>  $ doy                         : num  152 185 235 275 #>  $ hour                        : num  12 12 12 12 #>  $ time                        : num  3636 4428 5628 6588 #>  $ leaf                        : num  0.0504 0.2232 2.2917 0 #>  $ stem                        : num  0.0063 0.1339 3.6012 1.3289 #>  $ root                        : num  0.0063 0.125 0.9821 0.4319 #>  $ pod                         : num  0 0 1.96 5.81 #>  $ leaf_litter                 : num  0 0 0.16 2.25 #>  $ stem_litter                 : num  0 0 0.075 0.75 #>  $ seed                        : num  NA NA NA 4.32 #>  $ SLA                         : num  NA 2 2.57 NA #>  $ LMA                         : num  NA 50 38.9 NA #>  $ LAI_from_LMA                : num  0 0.446 5.893 0 #>  $ row_spacing                 : num  0.7 0.7 0.7 0.7 #>  $ plant_spacing               : num  0.0385 0.0385 0.0385 0.0385 #>  $ planting_density            : num  150000 150000 150000 150000 #>  $ leaf_area_per_plant         : num  NA 83.3 1500 0 #>  $ LAI_from_planting_density   : num  0 0.309 5.56 0 #>  $ LAI_from_measured_population: num  0 0.274 5.036 0 #>  $ agb_per_area                : num  NA 0.357 7.857 7.143 #>  $ agb_per_plant_row           : num  NA 1.09 23.4 19.61 #>  $ agb_per_plant_partitioning  : num  NA 0.667 20 35.833 #>  $ measured_population         : num  NA 132973 135864 147426 #>  $ initial_seed                : num  0.063 NA NA NA xyplot(   leaf + stem + root + pod + leaf_litter + stem_litter ~ doy,   data = soybean_biomass,   type = 'b',   pch = 16,   auto = TRUE,   grid = TRUE,   xlab = 'Day of year (2022)',   ylab = 'Biomass (Mg / ha)' ) # Save the data as an R data file save(soybean_biomass, file = 'soybean_biomass.RData')  # Save the data as a CSV file write.csv(soybean_biomass, file = 'soybean_biomass.csv', row.names = FALSE)

what: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
text: convenience function accessing data record sheets included   BioCroField R package.

title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
code: access_sheet(sheet_name, sheet_type = 'pdf', open_sheet = TRUE)

title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
text: sheet_name base name sheet opened. sheet_type file type sheet opened. open_sheet logical value indicating whether open sheet.

title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
text: selected record sheet automatically opened appropriate   application open_sheet set TRUE. Several sheets available: Log Sheets: Log sheets available PDFs (sheet_type = 'pdf') Microsoft Word   documents (sheet_type = 'word').  'harvest': data record sheet recording information           crop harvest. Protocol Sheets: Protocol sheets available PDFs (sheet_type = 'pdf') Microsoft   Word documents (sheet_type = 'word').  'weighing_tissue': general protocol weighing dry tissue. Crop-Specific Guide Sheets: Crop-specific guide sheets available PDFs   (sheet_type = 'pdf').  'cowpea_guide' 'grain_sorghum_guide' 'maize_guide' 'soybean_guide'

title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
text: full path specified file.

title: Access a built-in data record sheet — access_sheet
code: # Get the full paths to all available sheets access_sheet('harvest', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/harvest.pdf" access_sheet('weighing_tissue', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/weighing_tissue.pdf" access_sheet('cowpea_guide', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/cowpea_guide.pdf" access_sheet('grain_sorghum_guide', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/grain_sorghum_guide.pdf" access_sheet('maize_guide', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/maize_guide.pdf" access_sheet('soybean_guide', open_sheet = FALSE) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/BioCroField/sheets/soybean_guide.pdf"  # Open the MS Word version of the harvest data sheet if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  access_sheet('harvest', sheet_type = 'word') } # }

what: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
text: Adds new row data.frame created biomass_table   represents initial seed biomass.

title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
code: add_seed_biomass(     biomass_df,     year = NA,     doy = NA,     hour = 12,     seed_mass = NA,     zero_when_missing = character(),     component_fractions = list(),     ...   )

title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
text: biomass_df data frame assumed created biomass_table. year year crop grown, 2022. doy day year plot sown, 150. hour hour day plot sown. seed_mass average mass per seed (g), typically determined weighing     known number seeds (one hundred seeds). zero_when_missing character vector indicating biomass columns whose values set     zero explicitly measured. component_fractions list named numeric elements whose values must add 1. BioCro     simulations, often necessary estimate initial leaf, stem,     root biomass fractions original seed biomass. example,     assume initial mass 80     set component_fractions     list(leaf = 0.8, stem = 0.1, root = 0.1). ... additional arguments (comments) include columns new     row.

title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
text: new row data table constructed follows: values crop, variety, location,           planting_density, row_spacing, plant_spacing           copied first row biomass_df. values year, doy, hour taken           inputs; value time calculated           process. value LAI estimates (LAI_from_LMA,           LAI_from_planting_density,           LAI_from_measured_population) set 0 since           leaf area corresponding seeds just sown. initial seed biomass per unit ground area (Mg / ha)           stored new column called initial_seed. value           calculated using           initial_seed = seed_mass * planting_density * 2.47e-6,           factor 2.47e-6 converts g / acre           Mg / ha using 1 g / acre = 2.47e-6 Mg / ha. component fractions specified, values columns           set corresponding fractions initial_seed.

title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
text: data frame described .

title: Initial biomass from seed information — add_seed_biomass
code: # Example: Creating and processing a harvest_point object that includes # (optional) comments about the stem and the leaf litter, and then adding an # initial seed biomass (and another comment). hp <- harvest_point(   crop = 'soybean',   variety = 'ld11',   location = 'energy farm',   plot = 1,   year = 2023,   doy = 186,   hour = 12,   planting_density = 125000,   row_spacing = 0.7,   partitioning_leaf_area = 500,   partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 2.5, stem = 1.5, root = 1.4, leaf_litter = 0.2),   agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'),   agb_row_length = 2,   agb_weight = 50,   trap_area = 0.185,   trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 0.4, stem_litter = 0.5),   partitioning_nplants = 6,   agb_nplants = 50,   stem_comment = 'The stem weight includes petioles',   stem_litter_comment = 'The stem litter is entirely petioles',   leaf_litter_comment = 'Senesced leaves were present on the plants and in the trap' )  hpp <- process(hp)  biomass <- biomass_table(hpp)  biomass <- add_seed_biomass(   biomass,   year = 2023,   doy = 152,   hour = 12,   seed_mass = 0.17,   component_fractions = list(leaf = 0.8, stem = 0.1, root = 0.1),   seed_comment = 'Sown with precision planter' )  str(biomass) #> 'data.frame':	2 obs. of  31 variables: #>  $ crop                        : chr  "soybean" "soybean" #>  $ variety                     : chr  "ld11" "ld11" #>  $ what: Create a crop-specific guide to harvesting and weighing tissue — generate_crop_guide

code: generate_crop_guide(     crop_name,     uses_litter_trap,     notes,     harvesting_specific_tissues,     weighing_specific_tissues,     all_possible_weights,     build = FALSE,     output_dir = '.',     clean = TRUE   )

title: Create a crop-specific guide to harvesting and weighing tissue — generate_crop_guide
text: crop_name name crop. uses_litter_trap logical value indicating whether litter traps used     crop. notes Basic notes crop, appear just title     document. harvesting_specific_tissues named list, name element name tissue type,     value element string describing tissue type     harvested. weighing_specific_tissues named list, name element name tissue type,     value element string describing tissue type     weighed. all_possible_weights list two elements named living litter.     string vector describing possible types living senesced     tissue might collected crop. build logical value indicating whether automatically build PDF. output_dir path output directory PDF built (relevant     build TRUE). clean logical value passed render     building PDF.

title: Create a crop-specific guide to harvesting and weighing tissue — generate_crop_guide
text: function can used easily generate basic guide harvesting   weighing tissue particular crop. generate_crop_guide used internally generate crop guides   included BioCroField package. script used generate   guides also included package can located   computer typing   system.file('build_crop_sheets.R', package = 'BioCroField'). See   access_sheet details accessing pre-built guides. Ideally, crop guide fit one page can printed kept   hand reference harvesting weighing. Building guide sheets requires LaTeX. system-wide   LaTeX installation, may need use TinyTex package.   , make sure package installed run   tinytex::install_tinytex(). TinyTex can installed CRAN   typing install.packages('TinyTex').

title: Create a crop-specific guide to harvesting and weighing tissue — generate_crop_guide
text: text string rmarkdown code can written   file (writeLines) built PDF (  render).

title: Create a crop-specific guide to harvesting and weighing tissue — generate_crop_guide
code: # A simple example with some basic soybean information. Here we generate the # rmarkdown code but do not build the document. Change `build` to `TRUE` to see # what the final document looks like. markdown_file_contents <- generate_crop_guide(     crop_name = 'Soybean',     uses_litter_trap = TRUE,     notes = 'This is an incomplete example.',     harvesting_specific_tissues = list(       Leaves = 'These should always be harvested.',       Stems = 'These should also always be harvested.'     ),     weighing_specific_tissues = list(       Leaves = 'Only weigh the green ones. Brown ones count as litter.',       Stems = 'Just open the bag and weigh what you find inside.'     ),     all_possible_weights = list(       living = c('Roots', 'Leaves', 'Stems', 'Pods'),       litter = c('Leaf', 'Stem')     ),     build = FALSE )  cat(markdown_file_contents) #> --- #> title: "Soybean Guide (BioCroField)" #> output: pdf_document #> geometry: top=0.5in,bottom=0.75in,left=0.75in,right=0.75in #> --- #>  #> **Notes**: This is an incomplete example. #>  #> # Harvesting and Partitioning Soybean Tissue #>  #> - **Essential Tissue Types**: Every harvest should include above-ground biomass, #>   leaf, stem, and root tissue. When the plants are young, this might be all of #>   the tissue types. As the plants enter reproductive stages, additional types #>   might appear. #>  #> - **Plant Litter**: Any senesced tissue still attached to the plants themselves #>   is considered to be "plant litter." Plant litter should be included when #>   collecting above-ground biomass samples. Plant litter from partitioned plants #>   should be placed in a bag labeled "litter" or "plant litter." #>  #> - **Litter Trap**: Any senesced tissue in the trap should be placed in a bag labeled "trap litter" #> to distinguish it from the "plant litter" described above. The trap might not #> contain any litter when the plants are young. #>  #> - **Leaves**: These should always be harvested. #>  #> - **Stems**: These should also always be harvested. #>  #> # Weighing the Partitioned Soybean Tissue #>  #> - **Roots**: Roots are cleaned in the field before drying, but they are usually #>   still a bit dirty. Before weighing the roots, remove any soil or other #>   obviously foreign material. A small screwdriver or a capped pen is often #>   useful for this purpose. Be careful, and try to avoid damaging the roots #>   themselves, because any small pieces that fall off might be difficult to #>   recover and weigh. #>  #> - **Plant Litter**: The plant litter should be sorted into components as #>   necessary, discarding any soil or foreign material. Each component should be #>   separately weighed and recorded in the "partitioned plant components" section #>   of the harvest log sheet. The name of these components should clearly indicate #>   they represent litter; for example, **Leaf Litter**. #>  #> - **Litter Trap**: The litter trap contents should be sorted into components as necessary, #> discarding any soil or foreign material. Each component should be separately #> weighed and recorded in the "litter trap components" section of the harvest log #> sheet. #>  #> - **Leaves**: Only weigh the green ones. Brown ones count as litter. #>  #> - **Stems**: Just open the bag and weigh what you find inside. #>  #> - **All Possible Components**: The following is a list of all possible tissue components that should be #> weighed, although not all of them will be present at every harvest: Roots, Leaves, Stems, Pods, Leaf Litter (plant), Stem Litter (plant), Leaf Litter (trap), Stem Litter (trap) #>  #> - **Unclear Cases**: If you are unsure about anything while weighing, please #>   contact the responsible person listed on the harvest record sheet.

title: Biomass data from one harvest — harvest_point
code: harvest_point(     crop = NA,     variety = NA,     location = NA,     plot = NA,     year = NA,     doy = NA,     hour = 12,     planting_density = NA,     row_spacing = NA,     plant_spacing = NA,     partitioning_nplants = NA,     partitioning_leaf_area = NA,     partitioning_component_weights = list(),     agb_nplants = NA,     agb_components = character(),     agb_row_length = NA,     agb_weight = NA,     trap_area = NA,     trap_component_weights = list(),     ...   )

title: Biomass data from one harvest — harvest_point
text: crop name crop, 'soybean'. variety name crop variety, 'ld11'. location name crop's location, 'energy farm'. plot name plot harvested, 2. year year crop grown, 2022. doy day year plot harvested, 180. hour hour day plot harvested. planting_density intended number plants per unit ground area plants / acre;     typically different actual plant population due     seeds fail emerge (reduces actual population) accidental     double-planting (increases actual population). row_spacing spacing rows plot (m). plant_spacing spacing plants along row (m). partitioning_nplants number plants chosen partitioning. partitioning_leaf_area total leaf area partitioned plants (cm^2). partitioning_component_weights list named numeric elements, name element indicates     plant component ('leaf') value element     indicates dry weight measured partitioned plants (    g). agb_nplants number plants harvested -ground biomass. agb_components character vector indicating partitioned components     added together determine -ground biomass partitioned     plants. agb_row_length length row harvested -ground biomass (m). agb_weight weight row section harvested -ground biomass (    g). trap_area area litter trap (m^2). trap_component_weights list named numeric elements, name element indicates     plant litter component ('leaf_litter') value     element indicates dry weight measured litter trap contents     (g). ... additional arguments (comments) include     harvest_point object.

title: Biomass data from one harvest — harvest_point
text: technical point view, harvest_point object simply R   list particular set named elements, can viewed modified   using standard R commands apply lists. input arguments   optional, user needs enter information actually   measured. Typically, harvest_point object passed   process convert raw measurements useful   quantities like mass per unit area leaf area index. Note planting density: seed /plant densities can   specified various ways. planting hand, convenient specify   row spacing spacing plants along row. using   precision planter, typical specify row spacing plant   population. either case, row spacing, plant spacing, plant   population related according   planting_density * row_spacing * plant_spacing = 4047; equation   assumes row plant spacings expressed m   density expressed plants per acre. used specified three   inputs (planting_density, row_spacing,   plant_spacing), harvest_point function check make   sure values consistent . two inputs   provided, value third automatically calculated.

code: # Example 1: Creating a harvest_point object that includes (optional) comments # about the stem and the leaf litter. hp <- harvest_point(   crop = 'soybean',   variety = 'ld11',   location = 'energy farm',   plot = 1,   year = 2023,   doy = 186,   planting_density = 140000,   row_spacing = 0.7,   partitioning_leaf_area = 500,   partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 2.5, stem = 1.5, root = 1.4, leaf_litter = 0.2),   agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'),   agb_row_length = 2,   agb_weight = 50,   trap_area = 0.185,   trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 0.4, stem_litter = 0.5),   partitioning_nplants = 6,   agb_nplants = 50,   stem_comment = 'The stem weight includes petioles',   stem_litter_comment = 'The stem litter is entirely petioles',   leaf_litter_comment = 'Senesced leaves were present on the plants and in the trap' )  str(hp) #> List of 20 #>  $ crop                          : chr "soybean" #>  $ variety                       : chr "ld11" #>  $ location                      : chr "energy farm" #>  $ plot                          : num 1 #>  $ year                          : num 2023 #>  $ doy                           : num 186 #>  $ hour partitioning_nplants          : num 6 #>  $ partitioning_leaf_area        : num 500 #>  $ partitioning_component_weights:List of 4 #>   ..$ leaf       : num 2.5 #>   ..$ stem       : num 1.5 #>   ..$ root       : num 1.4 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.2 #>  $ agb_components                : chr [1:2] "leaf" "stem" #>  $ agb_nplants                   : num 50 #>  $ agb_row_length                : num 2 #>  $ agb_weight                    : num 50 #>  $ trap_area                     : num 0.185 #>  $ trap_component_weights        :List of 2 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.4 #>   ..$ stem_litter: num 0.5 #>  $ additional_arguments          :List of 3 #>   ..$ stem_comment       : chr "The stem weight includes petioles" #>   ..$ stem_litter_comment: chr "The stem litter is entirely petioles" #>   ..$ leaf_litter_comment: chr "Senesced leaves were present on the plants and in the trap" #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "harvest_point" "list"  # Example 2: Determining the planting density (in plants per acre) from the row # and plant spacings (in m) harvest_point(row_spacing = 0.75, plant_spacing = 0.2)$planting_density #> [1] 26980

what: Process raw biomass data from one harvest — process
title: Process raw biomass data from one harvest — process
text: function processes raw biomass data stored   harvest_point object convert meaningful values.

title: Process raw biomass data from one harvest — process
code: process(x, ...)    # S3 method for class 'harvest_point' process(x, leaf_name = 'leaf', ...)

title: Process raw biomass data from one harvest — process
text: x harvest_point object. leaf_name string specifying name leaf tissue use calculating     leaf area index. Typically, leaf mass called 'leaf',     may sometimes similar name 'main_leaf'. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Process raw biomass data from one harvest — process
text: process function attempts make variety calculations using   information stored x. possible elements   x set NA, relevant calculations   require pieces information simply skipped, outputs   set NA. results calculations stored   new elements harvest_point object. detailed calculations follows: time: time determined doy           hour using add_time_to_weather_data. measured_population: number plants per unit ground area           (plants / acre can estimated row spacing           number plants harvested -ground biomass using           measured_population = agb_nplants / (agb_row_length * row_spacing) * 4047.           , factor 4047 converts area basis m^2           acre using 1 acre = 4047 m^2. agb_per_area: amount -ground biomass per unit           ground area (Mg / ha) plot can estimated           row spacing dry mass plants harvested -ground           biomass using           agb_per_area = agb_weight / (agb_row_length * row_spacing) * 1e-2.           , factor 1e-2 converts g / m^2           Mg / ha using 1 g / m^2 = 0.01 Mg / ha. agb_per_plant_row: amount -ground biomass per plant           (g / plant) can estimated row section harvested           -ground biomass using           agb_per_plant_row = agb_weight / agb_nplants.           value can compared agb_per_plant_partitioning           get idea variability plant size throughout plot. partitioning_agb_weight: -ground biomass (g)           plants selected partitioning can obtained adding           partitioning component weights components           designated part -ground biomass. example,           partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 1, stem = 2, root = 0.5)           agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'), -ground           biomass partitioned plants 1 + 2 = 3.           words, root mass included. agb_per_plant_partitioning: amount -ground biomass           per plant (g / plant) can estimated partitioned           plants using           agb_per_plant_partitioning = partitioning_agb_weight / agb_nplants.           value can compared agb_per_plant_row get           idea variability plant size throughout plot. relative_components: relative mass (dimensionless           g / g; normalized -ground biomass)           partitioned component can obtained dividing component's dry           mass partitioning_agb_weight. example,           partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 1, stem = 2, root = 0.5)           agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'),           partitioning_agb_weight = 3           relative_components = list(leaf = 1 / 3, stem = 2 / 3, root = 0.5 / 3). components_biocro: biomass per unit ground area (          Mg / ha, units used BioCro) can obtained           multiplying element relative_components           agb_per_area. LMA: leaf mass per unit leaf area (LMA; units           g / m^2) can calculated mass area           partitioned leaves using           LMA = partitioning_component_weights$leaf / partitioning_leaf_area * 1e4.           , factor 1e-4 converts g / cm^2           g / m^2 using 1 g / cm^2 = 1e-4 g / m^2. LAI_from_LMA: leaf area per unit ground area,           referred leaf area index (LAI; dimensionless           m^2 / m^2), can calculated leaf mass per unit area           LMA using LAI = components_biocro$leaf / LMA * 1e2.           , factor 1e2 converts leaf mass per unit area           Mg / ha g / m^2 using 1 Mg / ha = 100 g / m^2.           estimate LAI can compared estimates based           planting density measured population, stored           LAI_from_planting_density           LAI_from_measured_population, respectively. leaf_area_per_plant: leaf area per plant           cm^2 / plant can calculated partitioning leaf area           number plants partitioned. LAI_from_planting_density: LAI can estimated           planting density leaf area per plant using           LAI = planting_density * leaf_area_per_plant * 1e-4 / 4047.           , factor 1e-4 converts leaf area cm^2           m^2 factor 1 / 4047 converts population           plants / acre plants / m^2. estimate LAI can           compared estimates based LMA measured population,           stored LAI_from_LMA           LAI_from_measured_population, respectively. LAI_from_measured_population: LAI can estimated           measured population leaf area per plant using           LAI = measured_population * leaf_area_per_plant * 1e-4. ,           factor 1e-4 converts leaf area cm^2           m^2. estimate LAI can compared estimates           based LMA planting density, stored           LAI_from_LMA LAI_from_planting_density,           respectively. SLA: leaf mass per unit leaf area, referred           specific leaf area (SLA; units ha / Mg), can           calculated LMA using SLA = 1 / LMA * 1e2 factor           1e2 converts units m^2 / g ha / Mg. trap_components_biocro: biomass per unit ground area           tissue types collected litter trap (units           Mg / ha) can calculated dividing dry mass           component litter trap area multiplying 1e-2           convert g / m^2 Mg / ha. all_components_biocro: biomass per unit ground area (          Mg / ha) plant tissue types included           components_biocro trap_components_biocro stored           all_components_biocro. component present           lists, separate values added together. example,           components_biocro may include leaf_litter component           represents biomass senesced leaves still attached           plants, trap_components_biocro may contain           leaf_litter component representing biomass senesced           leaves fallen plant; case, value           leaf_litter all_components_biocro sum           two separate leaf litter biomass values. note LAI estimates: LAI estimated using LMA accurate   three methods, commonly used estimating LAI destructive   leaf area measurements (Bréda 2003). mass values unavailable, may   possible use method; case, estimates based   population can used instead. enough information available make   three estimates, can compared consistency   check estimate upper lower bounds LAI. References: Bréda, N. J. J. "Ground-based measurements leaf area index:           review methods, instruments current controversies." Journal           Experimental Botany 54, 2403–2417 (2003)           [doi:10.1093/jxb/erg263 ].

code: # Example: Creating and processing a harvest_point object that includes # (optional) comments about the stem and the leaf litter. hp <- harvest_point(   crop = 'soybean',   variety = 'ld11',   location = 'energy farm',   plot = 1,   year = 2023,   doy = 186,   hour = 12,   planting_density = 140000,   row_spacing = 0.7,   partitioning_leaf_area = 500,   partitioning_component_weights = list(leaf = 2.5, stem = 1.5, root = 1.4, leaf_litter = 0.2),   agb_components = c('leaf', 'stem'),   agb_row_length = 2,   agb_weight = 50,   trap_area = 0.185,   trap_component_weights = list(leaf_litter = 0.4, stem_litter = 0.5),   partitioning_nplants = 6,   agb_nplants = 50,   stem_comment = 'The stem weight includes petioles',   stem_litter_comment = 'The stem litter is entirely petioles',   leaf_litter_comment = 'Senesced leaves were present on the plants and in the trap' )  hpp <- process(hp)  str(hpp) #> List of 36 #>  $ crop                          : chr "soybean" #>  $ variety                       : chr "ld11" #>  $ location                      : chr "energy farm" #>  $ plot                          : num 1 #>  $ year                          : num 2023 #>  $ doy                           : num 186 #>  $ hour                          : num 12 #>  $ planting_density              : num 140000 #>  $ row_spacing                   : num 0.7 #>  $ plant_spacing                 : num 0.0413 #>  $ partitioning_nplants          : num 6 #>  $ partitioning_leaf_area        : num 500 #>  $ partitioning_component_weights:List of 4 #>   ..$ leaf       : num 2.5 #>   ..$ stem       : num 1.5 #>   ..$ root       : num 1.4 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.2 #>  $ agb_components                : chr [1:2] "leaf" "stem" #>  $ agb_nplants                   : num 50 #>  $ agb_row_length                : num 2 #>  $ agb_weight                    : num 50 #>  $ trap_area                     : num 0.185 #>  $ trap_component_weights        :List of 2 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.4 #>   ..$ stem_litter: num 0.5 #>  $ additional_arguments          :List of 3 #>   ..$ stem_comment       : chr "The stem weight includes petioles" #>   ..$ stem_litter_comment: chr "The stem litter is entirely petioles" #>   ..$ leaf_litter_comment: chr "Senesced leaves were present on the plants and in the trap" #>  $ time                          : num 4452 #>  $ partitioning_agb_weight       : num 4 #>  $ agb_per_plant_partitioning    : num 0.667 #>  $ agb_per_plant_row             : num 1 #>  $ measured_population           : num 144536 #>  $ agb_per_area                  : num 0.357 #>  $ relative_components           :List of 4 #>   ..$ leaf       : num 0.625 #>   ..$ stem       : num 0.375 #>   ..$ root       : num 0.35 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.05 #>  $ components_biocro             :List of 4 #>   ..$ leaf       : num 0.223 #>   ..$ stem       : num 0.134 #>   ..$ root       : num 0.125 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.0179 #>  $ LMA                           : num 50 #>  $ LAI_from_LMA                  : num 0.446 #>  $ LAI_from_planting_density     : num 0.288 #>  $ LAI_from_measured_population  : num 0.298 #>  $ leaf_area_per_plant           : num 83.3 #>  $ SLA                           : num 2 #>  $ trap_components_biocro        :List of 2 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.0216 #>   ..$ stem_litter: num 0.027 #>  $ all_components_biocro         :List of 5 #>   ..$ leaf       : num 0.223 #>   ..$ stem       : num 0.134 #>   ..$ root       : num 0.125 #>   ..$ leaf_litter: num 0.0395 #>   ..$ stem_litter: num 0.027 #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "harvest_point" "list"  # Example: Creating and processing a harvest point object that has `main_leaf` # rather than `leaf`. hp2 <- harvest_point(   partitioning_component_weights = list(main_leaf = 1),   partitioning_leaf_area = 2 )  print(process(hp2)$LMA)              # returns NA because no leaf weight was found #> [1] NA print(process(hp2, 'main_leaf')$LMA) # returns the correct value #> [1] 5000

title: BioCroField version 0.4.0
text: now possible specify extra columns returned output biomass_table. Values time now calculated using BioCro::add_time_to_weather_data ensure always consistent BioCro’s time definition. Values partitioned leaf mass can set NA creating harvest_point, treated leaf mass provided.

title: BioCroField version 0.3.0
text: LMA now included output biomass_table. New crop-specific guides harvesting weighing now available, along convenience function creating guides (generate_crop_guide). new sheets now mentioned main vignette (handling_biomass_measurements). new vignette added (images_from_the_field) illustrates parts harvesting weighing process using pictures field.

title: BioCroField version 0.2.0
text: Two new methods estimating LAI added process: LAI_from_planting_density LAI_from_measured_population. original LAI estimate renamed LAI LAI_from_LMA better indicate different estimates. Allow user (optionally) specify plant spacing additiong row spacing plant population creating harvest_point object. three specified, consistency check performed. two specified, value third calculated. add_seed_biomass now takes planting density input data frame. target_population renamed planting_density population renamed measured_population https://github.com/biocro/BioCroField/pull/3 https://github.com/biocro/BioCroField/pull/4 https://github.com/biocro/BioCroField/pull/5

title: BioCroField version 0.1.1
text: bug related partial name matching partitioning components detected fixed. short, value leaf mass supplied value leaf_litter supplied, leaf litter mass used process calculating LMA related properties, leading errors. Now, internal code use partial name matching, user able supply different name leaf tissue component standard name leaf. https://github.com/biocro/BioCroField/pull/2

title: BioCroField version 0.1.0
text: first version BioCroField. point, package state rapid development, changes described . reserving version 1.0.0 stable complete future release; , major changes increase minor version number.
